The Knicks' fortunes depend on the shooting accuracy of their starting backcourt.

When they lost to a banged-up Orlando Magic team last Friday at Madison Square Garden, Allan Houston (2 for 6) and Chris Childs (0 for 6) combined for 8 points. The next night, during a come-from-behind victory over the Hawks in Atlanta, the two combined for 25.
''We've been very inconsistent this season, but our backcourt hasn't been together as long as our frontcourt has been,'' Houston said. ''It's just a matter of time.''

But the Knicks do not have time. With seven regular-season games remaining, New York (53-22) trails first-place Miami (57-18) by four games in the Atlantic Division. The Heat defeated the Detroit Pistons tonight, 94-88.

And the Knicks have an arduous week ahead. They will play host to the Cleveland Cavaliers on Tuesday and the Chicago Bulls on Thursday, and visit the Heat for a Saturday matinee. The Cavaliers (38-37), who lost to Charlotte by 110-105 in overtime tonight, have their own problems. They are battling the Washington Bullets for the eighth and final Eastern Conference playoff berth.
